awd_titl_txt: HBCU-Excellence in Research: Radiative Effects of Biomass Burning Aerosols Laboratory and Field Measurements and Modeling of Climate and Health Impacts
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to improve understanding of the emissions of biomass burning and how this impacts air quality and climate. The work will focus on burning of fuels under a range of relative humidities. Further experiments will probe the light-absorbing properties of particles in these emissions and how those properties change when particles come in contact with mineral dust or when they undergo reactions as they age in the atmosphere. Finally, the research will investigate the impact that these particles have on cloud formation. All of this information will be useful for improving the ability to model the composition of the atmosphere.

The project will also enhance the atmospheric chemistry and physics research and training capacity at two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), North Carolina A&T State University (NCAT) and Howard University (HU) - two of only four HBCUs with a program in Atmospheric Sciences - by developing sustainable research collaborations with Colorado State University (CSU), a leading institution in Atmospheric Science. The specific research activities focus on understanding radiative properties of biomass burning aerosols and modeling their impacts on climate and health through involvement in laboratory and field campaigns. This effort will strengthen connections with multiple universities, national laboratories, and private companies while providing opportunities for a new generation of scientists to build cross-cultural relationships. The activities will enable underrepresented minorities to participate in large field measurement activities, to attend classes at a leading atmospheric science institution (CSU), and to work on aircraft based measurement systems.

The primary objectives of the project are to:
1. study the role of relative humidity in determining the optical properties of aerosols produced from biomass burning, 
2. determine whether the mineral dust or biomass burning components influence the optical properties of internally mixed particles more,
3. investigate the potential importance of particulate emissions from biomass burning,
4. quantify radiative and health impacts of biomass burning aerosols using the GEOS-Chem chemical transport model, and 
5. provide students the opportunity to participate in preparation for and analysis of data from biomass burning field campaigns.

In addition to training several graduate students, this project will increase the research capacity at both NCAT and HU.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main research goals of this 3year project were coordinated collaborative laboratory, field and modeling studies at NCAT, HU, CSU, and Aerodyne Research Inc., to investigate the change in optical and chemical properties of biomass burning (BB) aerosols as a function of relative humidity (RH) and aging conditions and investigate the change in aerosol optical properties of BB aerosols when mixed with mineral dust and modeling health impacts of emissions from multiple sources in Africa. The focus was on Biomass fuels from Sub-Sharan Africa. Some of the findings are

1.     There are two ways that aerosol can exert its impact on global climate: (1) by scattering the incoming solar radiation and (2) by acting as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN). Hygroscopicity ? the ability of aerosol to take up water vapor ? plays a significant role in both. The hygroscopicity of aerosols derived from common biomass fuels in East Africa were measured in this work. The result is reported in Journal Aerosol Science and Technology https://doi.org/10.1080/02786826.2023.2198587

2.     An emissions factor is a representative value that attempts to relate the quantity of a pollutant released to the atmosphere with an activity associated with the release of that pollutant. Emissions factors have long been the fundamental tool in developing national, regional, state, and local emissions inventories for air quality management decisions and in developing emissions control strategies. Even though Biomass fuels from Sub-Sharan Africa, Sub-Saharan Africa is a hotspot for biomass burning (BB)-derived carbonaceous aerosol emissions air quality and climate models used measurements done in Europe or North America. This research provided the first laboratory measurements of emission factors of pollutants from several biomass fuels from Africa. The result is reported in Journal of Geophysical Research-Atmosphere https://doi.org/10.1080/02786826.2020.1822512

3.     In the field study through the Fire Influence on Regional to Global Environments and Air Quality (FIREX-AQ) campaign we examined the variability of emission factors EFs of three wildfires (Nethker, Castle, and 204 Cow) during the 2019 Western US wildfire season using the Aerodyne Mobile Laboratory (AML) and compared them to previous studies. Based on the vegetation in these three fires, the Nethker and 204 Cow Fires Comparisons were made between AML-observed wildfires, aircraft observations, and the values in literature for EFs and emission ratios, with mixed agreement due to the high degree of variability caused by differences in burning condition i.e. smoldering or flaming fires quantified by a Modified combustion efficiency (MCE). Differences in MCE drove the diurnal EF differences. This research can also guide the updating of emission inventories and the development of integrated climate change mitigation and air quality policies to minimize the impact of BB on human health and climate. The result is under review by the Journal of Geophysical Research-Atmosphere 

4.     Air pollution in Africa is a significant public health issue responsible for 1.1 million premature deaths annually. It is critical to understand the emission sources responsible for the attributed deaths. The health implications of the emissions were investigated using GEOS-Chem to quantify the effects of (a) trash burning, (b) residential solid-fuel burning, and (c) open biomass burning (BB) (i.e., landscape fires) on ambient PM2.5 and PM2.5-attributable mortality in Africa. The result is reported in GeoHelath https://doi.org/10.1029/2022GH000673

5.     This work also proposed a relationship between mass mobility exponent- a quantity used to distinguish shape of smoke particles as spherical particles or interconnected fractals and Modified combustion efficiency (MCE). This finding can serve as a tool to assess whether the application of Mie theory-based calculations is justifiable or not. The result is reported in Journal Aerosol Science and Technologyhttps://doi.org/10.1080/02786826.2020.1822512 

6.     Investigating Air Quality in Palapye, Botswana using GEOS-Chem and Low-Cost Sensor networks, is work in progress preparation for submission in 2023,

\The results are disseminated in 4 published peer reviews publications 1 publication under review, and one is under preparation. 22 conference presentations and 5 seminar presentations were made to disseminate the results.

Educational goals were to engage STEM majors in Atmospheric and Air Quality Research through participation in field campaigns and working with industry to increase the number of minorities trained in the field of atmospheric science using the state-of-the-science measurement and modeling techniques. In this 3-year project 3PhD, 1 MS and 6 undergraduates participated and were trained. 1 MS student graduated and a PhD student is near completion. 1 postdoctoral fellow was trained in this project
